results.title: [John Robertson Duigan Film Collection: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
The John Robertson Duigan Collection is a collection of silent 9.5mm home movies filmed by early aviator and engineer John Robertson Duigan (1882–1951). The collection includes a Pathé-Baby 9.5mm film camera and projector owned by Duigan. The home movies provide an insight into the everyday lives of John and his family in Victoria, including picnics, trips to the Grampians and Colac, family snapshots and aeroplanes of the late 1920s.

This short film, originally shot on 9.5mm film, shows a parade with a marching band through a country town past a garage called Bridge Motors (likely Duigan’s garage in Yarrawonga), followed by a couple in a rowboat and a group of people cavorting on the banks of a river or lake wearing 1920s fashion.

results.title: [Royal guest XVI Olympiad 1956]
results.brief_description: A historical record of Prince Philip’s visit to Melbourne during the 1956 Olympic Games. Captures his airport arrival; the public lining Melbourne’s streets to greet the Prince; his visit to Government House; a parade on Swanston street showing a glimpse of Melbourne Town Hall; the opening ceremony at Olympic Games; Robert Menzies and Prince Philip arriving at the Olympic stadium; entrance of athletes at the opening ceremony; Ron Clarke’s memorable entrance into the stadium and the lighting of the Olympic flame; footage of Station Pier in Port Melbourne; Philip arriving at St Paul’s cathedral in Melbourne; an extensive tour of the accomodation facilities prepared for the athletes at Olympic Village in Heidelberg; Philip visit a hospital and the Australian Paper Manufacturers mill in Heidelberg; shows footage of various track and field events in the stadium; a ceremony at Melbourne’s Shrine of Rememberance; the departure of Prince Philip.

results.title: Patsy Comes To Stay
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is a silent comedy narrative entitled ‘Patsy Comes to Stay’, which was produced by the Victorian Amateur Cine Society. The film was directed by H.J.D. Law and features Rankine as the Chief of Police.

results.title: All change please
results.brief_description:
A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Against the Grain” in association with Partners in Grain (PING).
“All change please. That’s what they say when the train is at the last station.” Diana Anderson began her journey around 23 years ago when she moved on to her husband’s family farm in north-west Victoria. Worked on for generations, Diana and Choco improved and changed the farming business, raising their two boys and enjoying the life for almost 23 years. That is until they were confronted with the distressing news the family partnership was to be sold. For Diana this was the end of one journey and the start of another - a new beginning.

group.title: Against the grain: digital storytelling project

results.title: Ekta
results.brief_description:
Please be advised: This film features flashing lights that may potentially trigger seizures for people with photosensitive epilepsy.

The Frank Eidlitz Collection contains the 16mm and 35mm film work of graphic designer and visual artist Frank Eidlitz (1923–1997), predominantly made during a Winston Churchill Fellowship at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), Cambridge in 1966. The collection contains Eidlitz’s experiments with light, movement and technology in film.

This film by Frank Eidlitz contains close-ups of art and design objects on display, as well as light experiments.

Objects that appear on film include details of a religious fresco, Jean Arps’ ‘Lion of the Cyclades: Seated’ (1957), metallic sculptures and glass prisms. Some sections are filmed within the exhibition ‘Light as a Creative Medium’, which was curated by Gyorgy Kepes at the Carpenter Center for the Visual Arts at Harvard University in 1965, organised in conjunction with MIT.

Interspersed throughout are some of Eidlitz’s light experiments, playing with light, colour and movement. The soundtrack is similarly experimental, consisting of fragments of music, radio voices and electronic noise.

results.title: Reminiscing
results.creator_credit: Alf Thornton, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Alf Thornton fondly recalls his time serving in the Australian Navy during World War II, when letting your mates down was more feared than being killed. When Thornton returned, he spent most of his time trying to regain his lost youth but eventually found an anchor on the H.M.A.S. Castlemaine.

results.title: Ceremony
results.creator_credit: David Greig and Experimental Film and Television Fund
results.brief_description: Nearly completing his painting, the artist takes a walk outside, where his creativity manifests itself in the life around him. This experimental work captures the ritualistic spirituality of art and the art in the everyday. Paintings in the film are by Paul Mason.

results.title: Yehinat fekir
results.brief_description: ‘Yehinat fekir’ means a mother’s love. I was born in Sudan and this is my story about my mother and how she struggled to bring us to Australia.
